facts.text: Appellant received Rs. 90,000 deposited by his sister in January 1946.

anchor.surface_text: The money in question was deposited with the appellant by his sister as far back as January 1946. The total amount deposited was Rs. 90,000/-, but the appellants sister took back Rs. 5,000/-, with the result that

facts.text: Appellant's sister took back Rs. 5,000 from the deposit, leaving balance of Rs. 85,000 with appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The total amount deposited was Rs. 90,000/-, but the appellants sister took back Rs. 5,000/-, with the result that the balance of Rs. 85,000/- remained deposited with the appellant. The appellants sister thereafte

facts.text: Appellant's sister migrated to Pakistan between June and August 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants sister thereafter migrated to Pakistan sometimes between June to August 1949. Sometime later, the Assistant Custodian General called upon the appelant to pay this sum lying in deposit under s. 48

facts.text: Assistant Custodian General called upon appellant to pay Rs. 85,000 under s. 48 of Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950.

facts.text: Appellant contested recovery claiming money was loan and recovery barred by January 1949 before sister's migration.

facts.text: Assistant Custodian directed recovery of Rs. 85,000 as arrears of land revenue under s. 48.

facts.text: Appeal to Custodian, Saurashtra failed.

anchor.surface_text: The matter was taken in appeal before the Custodian, Saurashtra, but the appeal failed. The appellant then went in revision to the Custodian General, and the revision also failed.

facts.text: Revision to Custodian General failed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then went in revision to the Custodian General, and the revision also failed. Then followed a writ petition by the appellant before the Saurashtra High Court in 1955.

facts.text: Writ petition filed by appellant before Saurashtra High Court in 1955; dismissed by single judge, succeeded on Letters Patent Appeal on December 9, 1957.

facts.text: Section 48 of the Act amended on October 22, 1956 by Act No. 91 of 1956.

facts.text: Notice of demand served on appellant by Assistant Custodian on January 22, 1958.

facts.text: Assistant Custodian directed recovery after hearing appellant's objections.

anchor.surface_text: and after hearing the objec- tions of the appellant, the Assistant Custodian again directed the amount to be recovered. The appellant then took the matter in appeal to the Custodian General.

facts.text: Custodian General allowed appeal in August 1958 and remanded for further enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then took the matter in appeal to the Custodian General. The Custodian General allowed the appeal in August 1958 and remanded the proceedings for further enquiry as directed by him.

facts.text: Custodian General held that amended s. 48 applies to proceedings from January 1958 notice.

facts.text: After remand, further evidence taken; held amount payable as deposit and recoverable when property vested.

anchor.surface_text: After the remand further evidence was taken and it was held that the amount in question was payable by the appellant as it was a deposit and was still recoverable when the property vested in the Custodian.

facts.text: Appeal to Custodian General dismissed on February 6, 1961.

facts.text: Special leave granted by Supreme Court.

facts.text: Property vested in Custodian on date of migration between June-August 1949.

anchor.surface_text: He was therefore of opinion that it would have to be determined when the sister of the appellant migrated and whether the amount was due to her on the date of her migration and had not become barred by the law of limitation on that date. issues.text: whether s. 48 as amended applies to recovery of actionable claims vesting in the Custodian or only s. 9 applies to physical property

anchor.surface_text: Section 9 deals with the recovery of immovable property or specific movable property which can be physically seized it does not deal with incorporeal evacuee property which may vest in the Custodian and which, for example, may be of the nature of an actionable claim. So far as actionable claims are concerned, they are dealt with by s. 48 as amended read with s. 10 (2) (i).

holdings.text: Sub-sections (1) and (2) of amended s.48 are clearly procedural and would apply to all cases which have to be investigated in accordance therewith after October 22, 1956, even though the claim may have arisen before the amended section was inserted in the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Sub- sections (1) and (2) are clearly procedural and would apply to all cases which have to be investigated in accordance therewith after October 22, 1956, even though the claim may have arisen before the amended section was inserted in the Act. It is well settled that procedural amendments to a law apply, in the absence of anything to the contrary, retrospectively in the sense that they apply to all actions after the date they come into force even though the actions may have begun earlier or the claim on which the action may be based may be of an anterior date.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural amendments apply retrospectively to pending or new investigations post-enactment unless contrary intent; applies to 1958 notice.

holdings.text: When the Assistant Custodian issued notice to the appellant on January 22, 1958 claiming the amount from him, the recovery could be dealt with under sub-ss. (1) and (2) of the amended s. 48, as they are merely procedural provisions.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, when the Assistant Custodian issued notice to the appellant on January 22, 1958 claiming the amount from him, the recovery could be dealt with under sub-ss. (1) and (2) of the amended s. 48, as they are merely procedural provisions. But it is urged on behalf of the appellant that sub-s. (1) in terms does not apply to the present case, and if so, sub-s. (2) would also not apply.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of procedural provisions to fresh 1958 proceedings initiated after amendment.

holdings.text: Section 9 deals with the recovery of immovable property or specific movable property which can be physically seized; it does not deal with incorporeal evacuee property such as an actionable claim. Actionable claims are dealt with by s. 48 as amended read with s. 10(2)(i).

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the argument is misconceived. Section 9 deals with the recovery of immovable property or specific movable property which can be physically seized it does not deal with incorporeal evacuee property which may vest in the Custodian and which, for example, may be of the nature of an actionable claim. So far as actionable claims are concerned, they are dealt with by s. 48 as amended read with s. 10 (2) (i).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual distinction between physical possession recovery under s.9 and sums due on incorporeal rights under s.48.

holdings.text: The contention of the appellant that s. 48(1) will not apply to the recovery of this sum of money must therefore fail and the Custodian would have the right to recover this sum of money as it is payable in respect of the evacuee property of the appellant's sister, namely, the right which she had to recover the sum from the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the appellant that s. 48 (1) will not apply to the recovery of this sum of money must therefore fail and the Custodian would have the right to recover this sum of money as it is payable in respect of the evacuee property of the appellants sister, namely, the right which she had to recover the sum from the appellant, and it is this right which vested in the Custodian.

holdings.reasoning_summary: The vested property is the actionable claim (right to recover deposit), not cash; sum payable 'in respect of' such property falls under s.48(1).

holdings.text: The appellant therefore cannot now for the first time in this Court take the plea that recovery could not be made under s. 48 and sub-s. (3) thereof would not apply even if the amount is treated as a deposit.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant therefore cannot now for the first time in this Court take the plea that recovery could not be made under s. 48 and sub-s. (3) thereof would not apply even if the amount is treated as a deposit. This contention thus raised in this Court for the first time raises a question as to the effect of sub-s. (3) of s. 48.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plea not raised before lower authorities; proceeded only on loan basis; raising now would require new evidence on facts like demand conditions and acknowledgments, not investigated below.

holdings.text: We are of opinion that there is force in this contention on behalf of the respondents and we are not prepared to allow the appellant to raise the question whether the recovery would be barred even if the amount is treated as a deposit.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that there is force in this contention on behalf of the respondents and we are not prepared to allow the appellant to raise the question whether the recovery would be barred even if the amount is treated as a deposit. In this view of the matter, it would not be necessary to consider the exact effect of s. 48 (3) and to decide whether it will apply even to cases where the recovery had become barred under the Limitation Act before October 22, 1956.

holdings.reasoning_summary: New point raises factual issues not probed below; confines appellant to loan contention actually made.

holdings.text: The appellant is liable to pay Rs. 85,000/- to the Custodian.

anchor.surface_text: and the question involved is whether the appellant is liable to pay Rs. 85,000/-to the Custodian. The matter has a long history behind it which it is necessary to set out in order to understand the point now in dispute in the present appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dismisses appeal upholding lower courts on application of amended s.48 to actionable claim from deposit; rejects new pleas.

holdings.text: Further as this was a deposit, limitation would run at the earliest from the date of demand and there is no evidence that any demand was made by the appellants sister for the return of the money before she migrated to Pakistan... Consequently the right of the appellants sister to recover the amount vested in the Custodian and was not barred by limitation at the time when she became an evacuee.

anchor.surface_text: Further as this was a deposit, limitation would run at the earliest from the date of demand and there is no evidence that any demand was made by the appellants sister for the return of the money before she migrated to Pakistan. Therefore, the period of limitation had not even begun to run on the date the appellants sister migrated to Pakistan, assuming art. 60 of the Limitation Act, No. 9 of 1908 applied.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.60 Limitation Act; no pre-migration demand evidence; vesting in 1949 before limitation period starts; first demand 1952.

holdings.text: We therefore do not allow the appellant to raise the point that the recovery would be barred even if the amount was a deposit.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore do not allow the appellant to raise the point that the recovery would be barred even if the amount was a deposit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unnecessary to decide retrospective effect of s.48(3) due to procedural bar on new plea.

anchor.surface_text: Sub- sections (1) and (2) are clearly procedural and would apply to all cases which have to be investigated in accordance therewith after October 22, 1956, even though the claim may have arisen before the amended section was inserted in the Act. It is well settled that procedural amendments to a law apply, in the absence of anything to the contrary, retrospectively in the sense that they apply to all actions after the date they come into force even though the actions may have begun earlier or the claim on which the action may be based may be of an anterior date.

Sub- sections (1) and (2) are clearly procedural and would apply to all cases which have to be investigated in accordance therewith after October 22, 1956, even though the claim may have arisen before the amended section was inserted in the Act. It is well settled that procedural amendments to a law apply, in the absence of anything to the contrary, retrospectively in the sense that they apply to all actions after the date they come into force even though the actions may have begun earlier or the claim on which the action may be based may be of an anterior date.

(1) and (2) of the amended s. 48, as they are merely procedural provisions. But it is urged on behalf of the appellant that sub-s. (1) in terms does not apply to the present case, and if so, sub-s. (2) would also not apply.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the argument is misconceived. Section 9 deals with the recovery of immovable property or specific movable property which can be physically seized it does not deal with incorporeal evacuee property which may vest in the Custodian and which, for example, may be of the nature of an actionable claim. So far as actionable claims are concerned, they are dealt with by s. 48 as amended read with s. 10 (2) (i).

We are of opinion that the argument is misconceived. Section 9 deals with the recovery of immovable property or specific movable property which can be physically seized it does not deal with incorporeal evacuee property which may vest in the Custodian and which, for example, may be of the nature of an actionable claim. So far as actionable claims are concerned, they are dealt with by s. 48 as amended read with s. 10 (2) (i).

anchor.surface_text: The appellant therefore cannot now for the first time in this Court take the plea that recovery could not be made under s. 48 and sub-s. (3) thereof would not apply even if the amount is treated as a deposit. This contention thus raised in this Court for the first time raises a question as to the effect of sub-s. (3) of s. 48.

The appellant therefore cannot now for the first time in this Court take the plea that recovery could not be made under s. 48 and sub-s. (3) thereof would not apply even if the amount is treated as a deposit. This contention thus raised in this Court for the first time raises a question as to the effect of sub-s. (3) of s. 48.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that there is force in this contention on behalf of the respondents and we are not prepared to allow the appellant to raise the question whether the recovery would be barred even if the amount is treated as a deposit.
